text: hi everyone anthony
trotano here the internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review of
this new uh little sims project
sometimes i might be introvert this is a
brand new record from uk rapper and
songwriter little sims following up her
excellent 2019 lp gray area which was a
short but bold series of bangers where
sims boastful bars rode some pretty raw
production and also a change of pace
from the lush and wondrous sounds that
she kind of built stillness and
wonderland off of previously and now
sometimes i might be introvert is
reminding me just how much of a
departure gray area was from wonderland
because this project sees sims leaning
back into her love of soul r and b and
more lush instrumentals but now with a
much more grand and theatrical
presentation and while introvert may not
be as hard or as overly aggressive as
gray area the creative ceiling on this
more versatile and dynamic sound is most
likely higher especially considering
sims is reaching for the stars on this
lp with these huge string sections
bright horn layers as well as a really
sweet children's group choruses the
content on this lp is pretty rewarding
too as sims dives into her past her
personal and emotional struggles her
family love and this lp also functions
as a celebration of women blackness art
with sims also framing her trajectory
through the music world as like a
fantastical or even spiritual journey
there are even multiple interludes and
passages on the lp where sims is being
addressed by like a fairy
godmother-esque
character which i do personally feel
like is a bit much and these spots don't
always connect aesthetically but i still
do appreciate these tracks for their
creativity in the narrative building
they add to this record as well with
sims pursuing her passions while
overcoming self-doubt and her tendency
toward introversion this inner struggles
given the gravity of the crusades on the
opening track of the lp with lots of
immense sparkling orchestral
instrumentation lyrics that give nods to
sinners churches kingdoms war which all
read like representations of the nagging
thoughts personality traits and identity
characteristics that are all kind of
pulling at each other within her there
is a spoken word line on the outro that
i think kind of sums the energy of this
track up the base is an amalgamation of
everything the following woman with cleo
soul is a gorgeous and jazzy tribute to
women of color it's charismatic it's
classy it is as flawless as the ladies
it describes then two worlds apart is a
very laid back intoxicating number with
super sweet hooky and purposeful soul
chops whose world apart mantra kind of
foreshadows the progression of the track
narratively which moves from this very
idyllic sort of love to something much
more toxic and distant with sims feeling
traded in in a way but still bouncing
back eventually claiming to be in a
better place and living on artists
actor money then i love you i hate you
also deals in love and uh hey there is a
yin and yang dichotomy when it comes to
sim's pursuit of music on this track her
feelings around her father respectively
balancing feelings of love and hate and
fear and need and hesitation in these
moments but what i want to highlight on
this track is conceptually and
instrumentally this song is a master
class in song structure from the
storytelling to the way sims's bars
develop on each verse
and kind of coalesce with
these builds of just grand and gorgeous
instrumentation the strings the horn the
harp are all amazing it just all comes
together so nicely and the way she's
able to effectively tie her bars into
those soul samples of i love you and i
hate you it's just perfect then little q
parts one and two see sims going down
memory lane with these cheerful kids
choruses that are kanye west college
dropout all the way she describes her
upbringing in gritty detail on
this track and i won't go into every
single you know bit of the narrative on
the song but i will say like as far as
the overarching themes of this lp it
would seem
that her introversion kind of gave her
the quiet focus to navigate these really
tough situations bringing that together
with the hope of a brighter day tomorrow
it's a track that deals in a lot of pain
and tragedy yes but also a lot of
triumph toward the end then the song
speed brings a very boastful vibe to the
track list a more of an aggression that
kind of hits in a gray area sort of way
but with an instrumental that has a
somewhat softer presentation with these
hand drums and some smooth synth leads
while it is a change of pace it mostly
fits into the track list and i do kind
of appreciate a groovy pick-me-up at
this point then the song standing
ovation is kind of like her jay-z black
album encore type moment where sims
reflects on fame what she did to get to
this point and what it all means to her
the writing the flows the performance on
sims's end is incredible the cinematic
instrumentation underneath her is
amazing and the track narratively comes
to a head toward the end where sims
launches her own personal ambitions into
i guess admiration for
figures that inspire her and a vision
for a better world the track i see you
is an intimate love number on the record
where i love the poetry i like that it's
low key but i think the instrumental on
this one it just runs a little too dry
there's something kind of flat about the
way it all comes together on this one
sonically for me and while i generally
like sims's wrapping there is kind of a
tendency for it to be monotone on
occasion which i don't think serves this
song the best then there's the massive
rapper came to t interlude that
is uh about as showy as these interludes
get with their
nods to musical theater and everything
and i i wish i loved these sections of
the record i wish they blew me away i
mean i do appreciate the ambition they
bring to the table but they just feel so
mismatched however don't let that stop
you from listening to this project i
think my issues with these sections of
the lp are like hyper specific to me and
again there are aspects of them that i
do like i like that they actually
effectively divvy up the album's many
avenues and sections the next few tracks
after this interlude bringing some
significant stylistic switch ups there's
roland stone which is an attempt at a
cold-blooded banger with a super minimal
beat a b switches well at one point and
sims playing a really low key from front
to back it's a somewhat trendy sound at
the moment i like that it is attempted
here and i guess it was fine as a teaser
but i'm just not seeing what it brings
to this
particular track list outside of the
narrative in the lyrics like sonically
and aesthetically it just feels so off
the beaten path in a way that's kind of
awkward and just out of place which is
also the case for protect my energy
though i do like the tune on this one a
little bit more this one has a sweet
vintage 80s synth pop throwback type of
feel the singing is not the best but
again the production is on point and i
do like narratively what this track
brings to the record sim's kind of
wanting to protect her
mental and emotional stability cutting
off things and or people that may be i
guess sort of endangering that favoring
loneliness over interpersonal toxicity
maybe that's that introversion kind of
creeping back in then point and kill and
fear no man are two of my favorites on
the record and they come almost as like
a two-for-one deal the first of which
brings some great west african
influences on the instrumental some
afrobeat horns as well it's low-key it's
groovy it's hypnotizing and i love the
vocal harmonies as well on here then we
have a smooth transition into the funky
drum circles steel drums and chanted
group vocals on fear no man where sims
rides the beat with a somewhat m.i.a
influenced flow that i like a lot the
record's really strong finish continues
with the last two tracks that kind of
close up shop narratively there is how
did you get here which in my opinion is
just like too beautiful for words the
crisp drums along with the elegant vocal
harmonies and pianos are excellent and
narratively speaking this is the fullest
and most thorough picture we're getting
of sims kind of illustrating this point
a point b progression from i was here at
one point i felt this way i was this
kind of person and now i have progressed
i become the person i imagined i would
always be i've advanced in my craft and
on top of it she she also makes it clear
that you know her success and her
progression isn't just about herself
it's not just about ego she's also kind
of pushed to do this as somebody who is
a student of of music a fan then the
closing track i think is almost like an
epilogue for the record the moment after
the closer where we get kind of a a
quiet and very solomon and introverted
sort of reflection
that is a lot more toned down and i
think we get more of a refocus on
the more personal things and everyday
things that that matter and kind of keep
sims afloat uh day to day you know those
personal connections with people who are
important to her we see almost like a
calming of some of those internal
emotional battles going on as well and
yeah it's just like a really great way i
think to finish this record up that is
again really immense really impressive
uh well put together and uh i think her
most ambitious work to date now overall
do i favor this record over gray area
not necessarily and that's not to sort
of put this record against that one or
say one is superior and inferior when it
comes to sims artistic progression i see
this record more as a project that is
kind of taking from where stillness in
wonderland took off because even though
that record fell short for me personally
i can't deny the fact that like sims was
really kind of going for something big
on
that project but like didn't quite make
it at least in my opinion i feel like
introvert here is like
so much closer to
this very versatile very large very
grand almost like you know janelle monae
arc android sized kind of artistic
statement well actually i won't even say
almost i would say in terms of like
grandiosity sims is very much there in
my opinion this thing is not perfect
from front to back but the moments that
are great are absolutely
positively awe-inspiring and i'm
genuinely happy we're seeing the
potential of sims first couple of
records come to fruition in a big and
undeniable way
on this lp i'm feeling a strong eight to
a light nine on this one tran position
have you given this album a listen did
you love it did you hate it what would
you rate it you're the best you're the
best what should i review next hit the
like if you like please subscribe and

anthony fantano
music little sims forever
